Happy MLK Day everyone. Dr. King figured importantly in my childhood. In 1963 my parents marched on Washington and can be seen in this treasured Life Magazine photo with other marchers dangling their feet in the Reflecting Pool. Five years later, when my father, Marcus Raskin, was indicted in the Boston 5 anti-draft conspiracy trial with Dr. Benjamin Spock, Reverend William Sloane Coffin, Michael Ferber and Mitchell Goodman, Dr. King sent my father a telegram saying that if the defendants were guilty for speaking out against the Vietnam War then he was guilty too. The kids in my family grew up with the comforting knowledge that Dr. Martin Luther King was on our side. The dazzling career and commitment of Reverend King are a constant inspiration for our people and a lodestar for America. Let his memory guide us through a gloomy time.

I'm not going to the inauguration. For the last couple of weeks, I have assumed that I would attend the inauguration of Donald Trump as a gesture of ritual constitutionalism, simply to witness the peaceful transfer of power to the new administration. But, as the hour approaches, I realize I cannot bring myself to go. I wish that these were normal times and that I could sit and applaud the normal workings of government. But these are not normal times and I cannot pretend as if they are. The moral and political legitimacy of this presidency are in the gravest doubt. I cannot risk my presence at Trump’s inauguration being interpreted as any kind of endorsement of his continuing business entanglements with foreign governments, his refusal to address the enormity of Russia's efforts to sabotage and undermine our democracy in 2016, his relentless trafficking in bigotry, misogyny, and fear, or his Twitter attacks on civil rights heroes, like my colleague Congressman John Lewis, union leaders and other citizens. I do not rejoice in this decision or take any pride in it any more than I would rejoice or take pride in going on Friday. This coming presidency is just a fact of life we'll all have to address best we can. I am afraid that these kinds of searing moral and political conflicts will be our destiny for a while.

Proud beyond measure to march with thousands of Marylanders, my daughters, and about 1 million other people today at the joyfully rebellious and historic Women's March on Washington. In America, "we the people" are not the fourth branch of government, some kind of erstwhile watchdog; we are the first branch of government, the fountain from which all power flows and the sovereign community whose rights you mess with at your own political peril. The overflowing, exuberant and resolute crowd that filled every nook and cranny of Capitol Hill today will simply not permit the new regime to dismantle the Bill of Rights, women's equality, or the social progress we have made over the last half-century. Globally, millions took to the streets to demonstrate that popular majorities are the real superpower on earth. This will be the critical counterforce to Trump and Putin and the league of dictators, despots and white nationalist polemicists that threaten democracy on earth. Human rights are women's rights, as Hillary said, and women's rights are human rights. The struggle for gender equality is the struggle for democracy.  This is what democracy looks like indeed, and it's also what a popular majority looks like. Thank you Maryland, and thank you America and the world for rising up today.

Excited about passage of H.J.Res. 76 and 92, two resolutions which I managed on the House floor yesterday that are intended to restore strong safety, oversight, and funding to our Metro system. These measures create a safety commission to assume effective safety oversight over Metro and allow for disbursal of millions of dollars in federal transit funds to Maryland, Virginia, and DC. We must redouble our efforts to get through our current problems with system safety, reliability and efficiency and to make sure that our more than 12,000 hard-working employees get the support they deserve. The Metro used to be the jewel of our region and it must be restored over time to its original grandeur. I remember in high school when Metro was completed--it was 1976 and it had a transformative effect on our region. Today it is the second largest subway system in America and takes two in five federal workers to and from work every day. Metro is also the way millions of Americans who come to visit the Nation's capital every year move around and get to see the White House, the Capitol, the museums and memorials, NIH, FDA, and so on. The Metro is thus critical, not just to the people who live and work here and make the federal Government and local economy function, but to all American citizens. Without it, our traffic gridlock would be impossible and indeed national security would be compromised. This is America's Metro and Congress must continue to work closely with Maryland, Virginia and D.C. to make the investments and safety and reliability reforms that will make Metro function in a way that makes us all proud again.

I write to salute all of my friends and constituents who engaged in the successful struggle to stop the destruction of health insurance coverage for millions of Americans.  In the dead of night, three honorable Republican Senators joined every Democratic Senator to soundly reject the final absurd entry in the manic and clandestine campaign to repeal the Affordable Care Act. But let us be clear why we won: popular organizing and mobilization prevented this catastrophe from happening. Without the calls, the letters, the massive attendance at Town Hall meetings, and the creative non-violent protests all over America, the GOP machinery would have gladly thrown 32 million Americans and their health insurance to the curb, sharply reduced Medicaid spending for our people, destroyed coverage for preexisting conditions, put Planned Parenthood in a straitjacket, and transferred hundreds of billions of dollars up the wealth ladder to the most prosperous people and corporations in our society.  So thanks to all the resolute Americans, including so many Marylanders, who said no to each “mean” farce of a plan and to the secretive smash-and-run legislative “process” that made a pure mockery of our democracy. This final result was an important victory for popular organizing, but now we must rebuild common ground across the political spectrum to make essential reforms to the health care system.  We need to restore the government’s power to negotiate with the pharmaceutical companies for lower prescription drug prices in the Medicare program—a power we already have in Medicaid and the VA.  We need to stabilize the Health Care Exchanges and lower premiums, co-pays, and deductibles.  We need to stop President Trump in his tracks as he continues his sickening efforts to sabotage the ACA from within. And we must work towards a system of quality health insurance coverage for all Americans, the kind of system that prevails in all the wealthy industrialized democracies of the world. "Tyranny, like hell, is not easily conquered,” said the great Tom Paine in Common Sense, "yet we have this consolation with us, that the harder the conflict, the more glorious the triumph.” Hang tough, America. We will make progress even through these dark times.

When Congressional votes were canceled this afternoon, I jumped at a long-standing invitation from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation to do a riverboat tour of the progress we are making in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. I collected my interns and joined up with CBF President Will Baker, CBF Vice President for Environmental Protection and Restoration Kim Coble, and my House colleagues and fellow Bay fanatics Dutch Ruppersberger (MD-02) and Scott Taylor (VA-02) to do an all-too-brief but happily bipartisan environmental expedition on the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers led by a CBF Captain born on Smith Island and expert in our region. Following the same tour that CBF does for thousands of schoolchildren in our states, we learned about all of the most up-to-date purification technologies and got this bright news: our Rivers and our Bay are getting cleaner and stronger each year. The blue crab population, the oysters, catfish and many different kinds of fish, and our six main grasses are all rebounding. Although the Bay is far from being healthy, the indicators are pointed in the right direction and the Bay dead zone is shrinking. Above all, water clarity and purity are dramatically improving. All of this progress is the result of decades of progress in sewage management, acid rain legislation, strict pollution controls and agricultural, urban and suburban storm water runoff prevention and management. Given the fine progress we're making through government in bringing back our still-delicate and always precarious watershed ecosystem, it is a pity and a scandal that President Trump is proposing to pull the plug on our progress and simply delete all federal funding for Chesapeake Bay clean-up. So far we have successfully resisted this terrible idea and have kept federal dollars flowing into Bay cleanup. But there is a strong political undertow today as polluters infiltrate every nook and cranny of the Trump administration and push Congressional Republicans hard to the right. I just voted against a terrible GOP amendment to keep the EPA from spending money to enforce pollution limits in the Bay region; alas, this piece of special-interest legislation passed in the House. Democrats and a few Republican friends will continue to fight against the climate change deniers and special-interest polluters every day to defend a strong federal role in the Bay cleanup to complement what the states, the District of Columbia, CBF, River Keepers and many other excellent environmental groups are doing. We won't let Trump, Ryan et al turn back the clock on environmental protection and we will never turn our backs on the Potomac River, the Anacostia River and the mighty and beautiful Chesapeake Bay.

As the Congressperson representing NIH, FDA, and NOAA, I fight hard for these institutions. NIH leads America’s scientific research and discovery related to fighting, treating and curing the killer diseases; FDA assures the safety and quality of our food and drugs; NOAA studies the oceans, the coastal regions, the weather and the climate to help the people and policymakers make the best decisions about our environment. I wish you could meet all of the amazing people I have met working in these agencies.   Cancer research is personal for me because I had colon cancer in 2010-11. The American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) asked me to tell the story of my year of living dangerously in its 2017 Cancer Progress Report, which was just released today. Each year, AACR publishes this excellent report outlining advances in cancer treatment and research, including research supported by NIH, and I was delighted to appear with other Members of the House Cancer Survivors Caucus on an AACR panel celebrating release of this report.   I was proud that my very first amendment passed in Congress increased cancer research funding by $10 million at NIH. Meantime, President Trump proposed an unconscionable 20% cut to NIH’s budget, which is $6 billion. We organized across party lines to stop that mad proposal to roll back research into cancer, heart disease, HIV/AIDS, asthma, Alzheimer’s disease, autism, cystic fibrosis, depression, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, and dozens of other serious diseases and conditions.  Instead we increased NIH’s budget by $2 billion in FY2017 and kept right on organizing. Both the House and Senate have now proposed to increase the NIH budget in FY2018 somewhere between$1.1 billion and $2 billion. I’ll be working closely with my Maryland colleagues from both chambers to fully-fund and support NIH’s invaluable work.  And, to all my fellow cancer survivors out there and everyone else struggling medically, I send you love, solidarity and encouragement.

In the global struggle to defend human rights and democratic freedom against authoritarianism, the people of the world have no greater friend and champion than the passionate Garry Kasparov, Chairman of the Human Rights Foundation (HRF) and the former world chess champion (1985-2000). In one of the greatest honors I have ever experienced, Kasparov came to visit me in my Hill office today. We talked about the repressive policies of Vladimir Putin that are strangling Russia, Putin’s ceaseless efforts to promote chaos and authoritarian politics in Europe, Asia and the United States, and the urgency of strong democratic action all over the world to defend human rights and the rule of law. We also talked about chess as a way to train young people how to think systematically and strategically, a passion of mine for two decades. And, then, in a dream come true, I got to play the grandmaster of chess (and human rights) in a game of chess in my office. The chess column reporter for The Washington Times, David Sands, was there and recorded all the moves so you’ll be able to reconstruct the game if you like. But it was the thrill of a lifetime; my chief of staff, Julie Tagen, said that she could not have imagined me any happier than if I had gotten to play piano with Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band. The game lasted a stunningly long time (20 minutes, basically because it took me so long to move) but, as I succumbed to the inexorable, Kasparov made my day by saying that I was a “solid” player and “very good and imaginative for a Congressman"! We are inviting Kasparov back to the 8th Congressional District when we open the new U.S. Chess Center facility in downtown Silver Spring (hurray!) in 2018. Stay tuned, chess and freedom-lovers. And fear not because while Trump plays golf and Putin goes fishing, we’re playing chess and we’ve got Garry Kasparov on our side.

America was shocked and horrified today by the deadliest gun massacre in our history. We stand united as a people in sending our thoughts, prayers and solidarity to the hundreds of wounded victims of the Las Vegas attack, the bereft loved ones of the 59 people murdered, all the re-traumatized victims of gun violence from Sandy Hook to Charleston to Columbine and beyond, and Nevada's heroic first responders, blood donors and citizen volunteers. On the Hill, Speaker Ryan conducted a brief moment of silence on the House floor tonight and then was off quickly to other business. But this is no time for silence and it is no time for business-as-usual, such as the macabre GOP/NRA proposals to legalize gun silencers and override the laws of 50 states to allow a national conceal-carry regime because there just are not enough concealed guns out there. I was proud to stand today with Gabby Giffords and her husband Mark Kelly as they called on Congress not to stop with "thoughts and prayers" but to engage in serious legislative action for effective policy change. We in Congress must indeed work overtime and across the aisle to pass common-sense legislation to lower our obscene rates of gun violence, beginning with universal background checks on all gun purchases, a legislative proposal backed by upwards of 90 percent of Americans. What takes place on Capitol Hill almost always seems divorced from reality, but today’s priorities have been nothing short of surreal. After the appalling Las Vegas massacre and amidst the massive suffering that continues in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, GOP leaders today chose to bring to the House floor legislation to ban abortions for the 2 percent of American women who have them after twenty weeks (overwhelmingly for reasons of profound fetal health problems). I only had a minute to speak in opposition, so I couldn't focus on this twisted sense of priorities, but I told the story of my constituent Allie, who faced an agonizing medical predicament and was able to use her constitutionally protected rights to end her pregnancy. Under the new bill advanced by the GOP, Allie's decision would have been illegal and her doctor would go to federal prison for five years as a convicted felon. Shocking when you think about it, this relentless assault on women’s health care. I hope that my GOP colleagues show the same vehement passion they have for the anti-abortion cause when it comes to protecting 33,000 American lives being snuffed out every year by rampant gun violence and swiss-cheese gun laws. But don’t hold your breath.  In a week when we should be working together to pass a universal background check (favored by 9 out of 10 Americans), a ban on high-capacity magazines and military-style assault weapons (the kind we passed in Maryland in 2013), and a restoration of the power of the Centers for Disease Control to study gun violence as a public health epidemic, the only firearm-related bills that have been slated for floor action are the GOP efforts to legalize gun silencers in the name of preventing hearing loss (I kid you not) and overriding the laws of 50 states to allow people with conceal-carry guns in their home state the freedom to pack heat everywhere. This sounds to me like the Mafia’s legislative agenda: concealed weapons and silencers. Now we’re hearing the bills may be delayed by GOP leaders out of “respect” for the Las Vegas families. Really? Why? If these atrocious bills will make us all safer, bring them on and let’s vote now.  If not, they should be withdrawn permanently. Why don’t we have hearings and a real legislative process?

The same public policy geniuses whose idea for health care was to throw 30 million people off their health insurance policies now have an equally amazing tax plan to sell America. It is a plan painstakingly prepared by the free-flying billionaire Cabinet of a billionaire President for the hard-pressed 1% of wealthiest Americans in our country. Yes, under the GOP plan, 80% of the total tax cuts will go to the wealthiest 1% of Americans, those who earn at least $900,000 a year or more. Got that? Fully 80% of the Trump tax cuts will go to people making more than $900,000 a year! Are you and your family in that rarified category of the “successful”?  If not, you may be one of the tens of millions of middle-class families who will actually have to pay more in taxes under the GOP plan. You see, if you come down to Capitol Hill, you will learn that middle-class people need to be taxed more to make them work harder while the richest people need to be taxed less to make sure they are not punished for being “successful.” So who benefits from this appalling scheme? Well, not to put too fine a point on it, President Donald Trump and his family do!  A New York Times analysis shows that Trump and his family are likely to save more than $1 billion under this plan. Of course, it’s impossible to know precisely how much President Trump will gain under this tax proposal, because he still refuses to release his tax returns, which is not only a radical breach of faith with the American people, whom he promised he would deliver his tax returns to if elected, but a radical break from past practice of presidents for the last half-century. In any event, the hard-working and public-spirited Trumps stand to gain hundreds of millions from the abolition of the estate tax, which now applies only to the richest one-half of one percent of Americans, and the repeal of the Alternative Minimum Tax, which is the only reason that Donald Trump paid any federal income taxes at all in 2005, the one year we know of in which he paid anything in the last two decades. But here’s the best part of this “plan” for America: according to the bipartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget’s estimate, it will add more than $2 trillion to the national deficit if we give these gargantuan sweetheart tax cuts to millionaires and billionaires. Two trillion dollars!  Whatever happened to the “deficit hawks,” like Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator Mitch McConnell and all my colleagues who have daily described our deficits and national debt as a moral and political crisis? Well, the deficit hawks have become deficit chicken-hawks and full-blown deficit-ostriches and deficit-peacocks. Strutting and clucking and squawking like big bad hawks when Barack Obama was president, they are now scurrying away and sticking their heads in the sand like ostriches although they may still parade around like deficit peacocks at election time.  Don’t fall for any of it. Tell the people about this dangerous plan and tell the GOP to send it back to Mar-a-Lago and the Trump Hotel where someone had some good belly laughs cooking it up.

Following the grand jury indictment of Paul Manafort and Rick Gates and all the reports of the President ‘seething’ and in an explosive mood, my colleagues and I are working hard to stop POTUS from waking up and firing Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Our letter:

I originally thought the GOP tax plan would be traditional run-of-the-mill upside-down class warfare, and on that front, of course, it does not disappoint: 80 percent of the proceeds of the proposed tax cut go to people making $912,000 a year or more, the top 1 percent of earners, and it reportedly repeals the estate tax for the lucky heirs of the same tiny group while abolishing the Alternative Minimum Tax (which is clearly Donald Trump’s personal nemesis). But it turns out there is a very special giant worm tucked in this newly delivered legislative apple: a shocking provision changing our tax system over to a “territorial” principle, which would mean a massive flight of capital and jobs out of America. Under this principle, if I set up a factory with 1,000 jobs on Main Street, I pay full taxes on profits every year to the IRS, but if I locate the factory and 1,000 jobs in Mexico, Singapore, or Switzerland, I will pay ZERO taxes on the profits—forever! Where do you think most businesses and jobs will be located and relocated from now on, at home or abroad? This dreadful lobbyist-concocted idea slipped into the Ryan-McConnell tax plan is a dagger pointed at the heart of our already battered American manufacturing sector, as well as our beleaguered unions and working class majority. How can we capture the extremism of this betrayal of our people or the sinister bait-and-switch involved in Donald Trump campaigning on a platform of putting America First and bringing jobs back home but the GOP Congress now proposing to ship millions more jobs overseas with these outrageous tax incentives? Where are the purported “economic nationalists”? Where is Steve Bannon? We must stand with labor to fight tooth-and-nail this 100 percent tax bonus for offshoring American jobs.

Since I entered Congress in January, there have been 397 mass killings by firearm in our country--that is, 397 gun-related massacres with four or more civilian casualties. Two of these mass killings have ranked among the ten worst firearm massacres of civilians in our history: the bloodbath in Las Vegas on October 1, which took the lives of 58 Americans and wounded more than 500, and the Sutherland Springs, Texas massacre which left 25 women, men and children dead. Thousands of our people have already lost their lives in 2017 and we have still a month to go in the year.   Well, yesterday, the GOP leadership in Congress finally decided to do something. A hearing on a universal criminal background check for all gun sales, a measure supported by more than 90% of the American people and by a majority of every political group? I can’t tell you how moving it was to join Democratic and Republican House colleagues, my extraordinary constituent Greg Simon-who led VP Biden's Cancer Moonshot Task Force-and health care advocates for the kick-off of the Congressional Cancer Survivors Caucus today. The purpose of our Caucus will be to unify across party lines to do whatever we can to prevent cancer, to improve the human environment, to expand the efficacy and availability of cancer treatment and health insurance, to aid and learn from survivors, and to end cancer in our time.   This is the way the legislative process should work. We can fight like cats and dogs during the campaign, but once we’re all in office, we should work together comprehensively, beyond party (which comes from the French word “partie,” a part of the whole), to advance the common good which we can recognize from our common humanity. The stories my colleagues told were both searing and inspiring.   You will recall that, back in 2010, when I was a State Senator and a professor of constitutional law, I was diagnosed with Stage 3 colorectal cancer. I did it all—radiation, chemotherapy, surgery, and ultimately veganism!—and was treated by some remarkable nurses and doctors from Johns Hopkins and Anne Arundel Medical Center who saved my life. Out of that experience I resolved to keep fighting for health care as a basic right for all our people. It’s scandalous that the wealthiest society in history compounds the medical misfortune of a bad diagnosis—and all of its attendant psychological, emotional, family and professional stress—with the hardship, anxiety and injustice of lack of insurance for millions of our people. It makes no sense to me.   My experience also strengthened my determination to make sure that (NIH) and the National Cancer Institute get the critical investments and funding they need to continue making breakthroughs against diseases like cancer.   Greg Simon, who is now President of the non-profit Biden Cancer Initiative, emphasizes developing patient-focused approaches to cancer research, care, and treatment. I look forward to fighting for dramatic progress with him and my colleagues, including Caucus Co-Chairs Reps. Mark DeSaulnier and Ted Poe, and fellow Caucus members, including Reps. Phil Roe, Doris O. Matsui, Kevin Yoder and Rick Nolan, whose daughter, Katherine, is a cancer survivor. There is so much more to do but this is a most promising start.

Yesterday my Dad, Marcus Goodman Raskin (1934-2017), died. It is difficult to express the enormity of our loss. He was a piano prodigy and musical sensation, a born philosopher and magical teacher, a political visionary, organizer and risk-taker, McGeorge Bundy’s Special Staff on President Kennedy’s National Security Council, co-founder of the Institute for Policy Studies, an anti-war leader, member of the Boston 5 prosecuted for (and acquitted of) conspiracy to “aid and abet” draft resistance during the Vietnam War for writing A Call to Resist Illegitimate Authority, a civil rights activist who marched with King and organized with SNCC, a Deweyean pragmatist and Sartrean hero, an exemplary citizen serious about law and impassioned for justice, a target on Nixon’s Enemies List, an exquisitely gentle and surpassingly strong father to four and uncle to two, a beloved grandfather to nine (nearly ten) and great-grandfather to one, a loving husband, an author of more than 20 books of political philosophy and engagement, an unstoppable chocolate and root beer lover, a teetotaler, a devourer of books and movies, a proud Washingtonian, a magnificent friend to the young and old alike, and an irreplaceable force for good in the world. Generations to come will cherish his memory and be inspired by his remarkable life.

Our whole family is overwhelmed by the outpouring of love and affection we have received for Marcus Raskin. We thank you for your wonderful consoling thoughts, your vivid reminiscences and your resolve to keep fighting for the kind of America and world he envisioned. Here is the first obituary we have received, from the Washington Post by Matt Schudel.

Here is another beautiful and stirring obituary about my Dad. Richard Sandomir’s article clarifies my father’s role in the release of the Pentagon Papers, something I had always wondered about. Thanks again to the thousands of people who have written our family with sympathy, solidarity and appreciation. Remember what The Nation’s Katrina vanden Heuvel reminded me yesterday: my Dad would be the first to want us all back at work for justice asap. Stay tuned for details on our Memorial Service on February 12, 2018 at 4:00 pm at the Sixth and I Historic Synagogue in Washington. Love from all the Raskins.
